poem:
"Resilience Sketched in Child's Crayon"

Held high, Daniel's name - each syllable
a silent cloud in a brittle sky,
a scholar bright, a football's flight,
a heart too good to say goodbye.
Braced by Bancroft's boughs,
where young Grace once soared,
He traces histories in the breath of trees,
Bearing the school's worn weight,
A silent sonnet to their shared story,
Gone, but cast in constellations of memory.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Hainault attack: school praises Daniel Anjorin’s ‘positive and gentle’ character The 14-year-old boy killed in the east London sword attacks was praised as a “true scholar”, gentle and a gifted footballer, as it emerged he attended the same school as one of the victims of the 2023 Nottingham stabbings. Daniel Anjorin, was a student at the private Bancroft’s school in Woodford Green, which is still reeling from losing the former student Grace O’Malley-Kumar in June". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
